Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of long service life vacuum insulation composites
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is focused on development of a novel manufacturing method for producing compartmentalized vacuum composites that exhibit superior thermal and structural efficiency. The proposed efforts will enable mass production of these materials and assembly into appropriate sizes and shapes, while maintaining vacuum inside the panels. The limited insulation capability and mechanical performance of foam-based insulation currently used for temperature-sensitive shipments require thicker walls and a large amount of cooling agent to maintain payload temperature. This reduces the payload volume and limits re-usability. There is an opportunity to develop highly insulating, structurally efficient materials that can significantly increase insulation capacity and longevity of cold chain shipping containers. Compartmentalized vacuum composite prototypes will be manufactured and tested for mechanical and thermal insulation properties using accredited testing methods. Key manufacturing and quality parameters will be confirmed for lab-scale and industrial-scale production. Successful completion of this work will result in a novel manufacturing method which will enable highly efficient (five to ten times improvement in insulation) cold chain shipping solutions. The proposed materials will provide sustainable economic and environmental benefits and are poised to replace polystyrene and vacuum insulation panels currently used in cold chain shipping.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project could eventually extend to cold chain shipping, storage, building insulation, automobiles, aerospace and other advanced markets. The first application is in the cold chain shipping industry for highly sensitive materials. Based on the proposed technology, a new generation of lightweight, evenly-insulated, durable, and long-lasting containers will be realized. Temperature-sensitive products such as life-saving vaccines and blood can be shipped using these containers. These containers will offer longer shipping duration, high impact resistance, and re-usability. Customers in the cold chain shipping market include blood banks, the Red Cross, pharmacies, clinical trial shippers, diagnostic centers, and life science material providers. The annual United States market potential in life sciences packaging is estimated at $291 million. Successful completion of the proposed objectives will result in a versatile insulating structural material that will also find application in infrastructure, automobiles, aircraft, marine, computing, commercial electronics and other household applications.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Phase I SBIR project, MaxQ has successfully demonstrated the technical and economic feasibility of fabricating compartmentalized vacuum core composite materials. Scalable methods for mass production have been developed and tested. Successful completion of Phase I SBIR work has resulted in cost effective (an order of magnitude lower), stronger (10x impact resistant compared to Styrofoam), light weight, thin (less than 1”), very-high insulation rating (R 16-22), compartmentalized vacuum composite materials. MaxQ has also demonstrated an exclusive machining capability where vacuum composites can be cut/sized, on-site without degradation in thermal performance unlike current state of the art Vacuum Insulation Panels (VIPs).  Current state of the art Vacuum Insulation Panels (VIPs) have systemic (single layer) vacuum barrier, they cannot be machined (processed on site) and require supplementary structural reinforcement for operational use. Mechanical and service life characteristics of the newly developed materials were also confirmed using industry standard ASTM test methods. Finally, scalability of the proposed process and composite was demonstrated by fabrication of large 4’x4’ panels.

 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is in cold chain shipping, storage, building insulation, automobiles, aerospace and other advanced markets. The first application is in the cold chain shipping industry in packaging and storage of highly sensitive materials. MaxQ envisions a new generation of thin (less than 1”), light weight, highly insulated (R value 25-30), durable, long service life containers that will not require redundant packaging materials used in current state of the art solutions. Temperature sensitive products such as life-saving vaccines, blood, organs and diagnostic specimens can be shipped using these containers. These offer longer shipping duration, high impact resistance, and re-usability.  Cold chain shipping market includes blood banks, Red Cross, pharmacies, clinical trial shippers, diagnostic centers, life science material providers and whole sale distributors. The annual United States market potential in life sciences packaging is estimated at $291M. Housing and commercial structures in densely populated high price per-square-foot locations will also tremendously benefit from the superior insulation benefits achieved in a lower footprint. Modular structures, trailers (subway coaches, yachts, boats, RV’s), temporary structures and shelters could exploit quantifiable energy savings in application of the proposed materials. Successful completion of the proposed work has resulted in higher efficiency, highly economical insulating materials that will provide sustainable cost savings in cold chain shipping by enabling customers to ship more (higher usable volume), ship farther (long temperature hold time) at lower costs while reducing payload loss. Users in the building/structural insulation markets will experience unmatched cost savings achieved through high energy efficiency, improved thermal performance and increased foot print.


Last Modified: 09/30/2014
Modified by: Saravankumar Shanmugavelayudam
